Title: How to prove $\frac{x}{1+x^2}<\arctan x<x$ for $x>0$?
Content: How to prove for $x>0$, $\dfrac{x}{1+x^2}<\arctan x<x$? I started with saying $0<\arctan x<\frac{\pi}{2}$  when $x>0$ I'm just not sure how to proceed with this proof, it works when I take random  values but I cant see how to prove that it works for any $x$.
AcceptedAnswer: For example: $$f(x):=\frac x{1+x^2}-\arctan x\implies f'(x)=\frac{1-x^2}{(1+x^2)^2}-\frac1{1+x^2}=-\frac{2x^2}{(1+x^2)^2} $$ Since clearly $\;f'(x)\le 0\;\;\forall\,x\ge0\;$ , and in fact $\;f'(x)<0\;\;\forall\,x>0\;$ , the function is monotone descending, so $$\forall\;x>0\;,\;f(x)<f(0)=0\;\;\text{and we're done with the leftmost inequality}$$ Now you try the rightmost inequality (very similar trick)
